{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} '''Victoria Roberts''' is a [[cartoonist]] and performer.<ref>{{citation | title = Victoria Roberts | url = http://www.victoriaroberts.com/}}.</ref> A staff cartoonist for ''[[The New Yorker]]'' since 1988,<ref>{{citation | publisher = The New Yorker | title = Cartoonists | url = http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/cartoonists}}.</ref> Roberts' work has also appeared in ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'', ''[[Ms. Magazine]]'', and many other magazines and newspapers.<ref name= "H Post">{{cite web|title= Victoria Roberts|url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/victoria-roberts|publisher= [[Huffington Post]]|accessdate= 12 June 2011}}</ref> She illustrates the Q&A weekly science question in ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref>{{cite news | last = Ray|first=C. Claiborne|title= Science Q&A—Flies in the Dark|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/07/science/07qna.html?_r=1&ref=science|accessdate=12 June 2011|newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date= 6 June 2011}}</ref> She was called Australia's most successful female cartoonist by ''[[The Age]]''.<ref name="Age"/> She is the author of ''After the Fall'', published by [[W. W. Norton and Company]] in November 2012.
Her style has been described as whimsical, and according to ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'', "there is delight, and childish embellishments".<ref name=herald1984>{{cite news|last= Thompson|first= Tom| title = Incredulous Victoria and her whimsical menagerie|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=3DFWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IucDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4801,6343924&dq=victoria-roberts+the+sydney+morning+herald+-judge&hl=en |accessdate=12 June 2011|newspaper= [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=13 July 1984}}</ref> In her own words, she likes "to draw fat little ladies with hearing aids, weird infants with glasses, and domestic scenes; I see things as people at home see them".<ref name="Age"/>
Her first cartoon strip, “My Sunday” appeared weekly in Australia’s ''[[Nation Review]]'' when she was nineteen. In the strip, Roberts illustrates the hypothetical Sundays of famous people.<ref name=Age>{{cite news|last=King|first=Elisabeth|title=My Sunday—Victoria Roberts: Cartoonist|url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=SxlVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yJMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2638,1613945&dq=victoria-roberts+cartoonist&hl=en |accessdate= 12 June 2011|newspaper= [[The Age]]|date= 13 February 1987}}</ref> Roberts has written and/or illustrated over 20 books, and received several grants, awards, and residencies, including an [[Australian Bicentennial]] grant for ''Australia Felix'', a [[Graphic non-fiction|cartoon history]] of Australia published by Chatto & Windus.<ref>{{cite news|last=Jones|first= Margaret|title= Birthday Culture May Offend|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=oipWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oeQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1749,2415325&dq=australian+bicentennial+grant+victoria-roberts&hl=en|accessdate=12 June 2011| newspaper = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=20 February 1987}}</ref><ref name=daao>{{cite web|title=Victoria Roberts|url=http://www.daao.org.au/bio/victoria-roberts/#artist_biography|publisher=Design and Art Australia Online|accessdate=12 June 2011}}</ref>
Roberts has also worked in animation. Credits include “Goodbye Sally Goldstein” and “The Maitland and Morpeth Quartet”, and also in radio, recording “Divinity Fudge” for [[WNYC]], and “The Life of [[Truman Capote]]” for [[ABC Radio Australia]].<ref name="H Post"/>
Since 2004, she has appeared on stage as her earliest cartoon character Nona Appleby. Nona is a [[kimono]]-clad Australian octogenarian. Her first solo show, Nona, opened at the National Museum for Women in [[Washington D.C.]] in 2005, and went on to a season at Urban Stages in [[New York City]].<ref name="NY Times">{{cite news|last=Weinert|first=Laura|title=Give the Ladies the Mike for a Bit of Poetry and Comedy|url=http://theater.nytimes.com/2006/02/24/theater/reviews/24verg.html|accessdate=12 June 2011|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=24 February 2006}}</ref>
Born in Manhattan, Roberts grew up in Mexico City and Sydney. She lives in New York City and Mexico.<ref>{{cite web|last=Roberts, Victoria |title= Victoria Roberts cartoonist – Resume|url=http://victoriaroberts.net/resume|accessdate=12 June 2011}}</ref>
